steps.title: Figure out what type of face skin you have.
steps.content: Figure out what type of face skin you have. Your skin changes as you age, especially during puberty, and looking for products in the skincare aisle at the drugstore can be confusing. There are so many options! Which should you choose? To find the right cleanser for your skin, it is important to first determine your current skin type: Normal skin is not too oily and not too dry, with minimal blemishes and no severe sensitivity to products or weather. Oily skin often appears shiny or greasy, even if you recently washed your face. Oily skin is also prone to blemishes and larger pores. Dry skin is often flaky, with more visible lines and some reddish patches of skin. Sensitive skin is often mistaken for dry skin because it typically appears dry and red; however, the difference is that sensitive skin is often a result of a particular ingredient in a skin care product. Combination skin is when you have patches of skin that are oily in some areas and dry or normal in others. Combination skin is typically oily around the T-zone (the T-shaped area created by your forehead, nose, and chin) and normal to dry on the rest of the face.

steps.title: Wash your hands first.
steps.content: Wash your hands first. Before you start cleansing the skin on your face, be sure to wash your hands with warm water and soap to kill all the germs and remove dirt and grime. You wouldn't want to rub more germs all over your face, would you?

steps.title: Wash your face
steps.content: Wash your face twice a day with lukewarm water and a gentle cleanser. [2] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Even if your skin looks clean, it's probably not. It is very important to cleanse your face every morning and every night before bed, especially if you wear makeup or are prone to breakouts. Keep in mind: [3] X Research source Don't use water that is extremely hot or extremely cold since this can damage your skin and trap grease and dirt inside your pores. Gently massage your face with slow, circular motions. Don't scrub! Scrubbing will cause skin irritation, redness, or breakouts. Treat the skin around your eyes extra gently, as it is the most delicate, sensitive skin on your face. Plus you don't want to end up with cleanser in your eyes! Don't over-wash your face! Even if you have oily skin, over-washing can cause dryness, and your skin will produce more oil to compensate, which means you could end up with oilier, more blemished skin. Reader Poll: We asked 799 wikiHow readers how many products they use in their skincare routine, and 56% of them agreed that they just use water or maybe 1 product. [Take Poll] Until you know what works best for your skin, experiment with different products and routines, then adjust to match your skinâ€™s needs.

steps.title: Find out if exfoliation is right for your skin.
steps.content: Find out if exfoliation is right for your skin. For some skin types and conditions, exfoliating can be helpful, such as those with sun damage. However, for other skin types, such as those with cystic acne, exfoliating can damage your skin. Check with a dermatologist to be sure if exfoliating is right for you. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Choose a scrub that's designed for your skin type and that is not too harsh. Some varieties include: Mild scrubs containing beads, sugar, salt or other types of natural exfoliators. Soft skincare brushes. These can be manual or oscillating brushes that you squeeze your cleanser or a mild scrub into before gently rubbing the brush on your face. Treatment masks that include mild acids like alpha-hydroxy acid or beta-hydroxy acid to slough off dead skin. Be very careful with this option and be sure to read the directions!

steps.title: Rinse your face thoroughly after cleansing or exfoliating.
steps.content: Rinse your face thoroughly after cleansing or exfoliating. Using lukewarm water, gently rinse the cleanser from your face either with a clean washcloth or by cupping your hands under the sink and carefully splashing water onto your face. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Be sure all of the cleanser is removed, as any remaining cleanser can clog your pores and cause irritation and blemishes. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Pat your face dry with a clean, soft cloth.
steps.content: Pat your face dry with a clean, soft cloth. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Never dry your skin with a dirty hand towel in the bathroom or the same towel you use to dry off your body; you will just transfer new, fresh bacteria onto your clean face. Also, it is important to pat, not rub, your face dry in order to treat the skin as gently as possible.

steps.title: Moisturize your face.
steps.content: Moisturize your face. Apply moisturizer to your face after you dry it off. [8] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Many people skip this step, but applying a moisturizer designed for your particular skin type is very important post-cleansing. Moisturizers seal in the existing water in your skin so it doesn't evaporate, which dries out your skin. You may need more moisturizer, or a thicker moisturizer, during the winter months.

steps.title: Shower or bathe every day using warm-to-hot water.
steps.content: Shower or bathe every day using warm-to-hot water. In addition to removing dirt and oil that can cause body acne, showering or bathing once a day will help wash away the bacteria that causes body odor. While very hot water should be avoided because it strips the skin of important oils, use warmer water when cleaning your body than you would on your face in order to kill the bacteria.

steps.title: Cleanse your body in the shower or bath safely.
steps.content: Cleanse your body in the shower or bath safely. As with cleaning your face, it is important that your hands and the products you use to clean your body are hygienic. Bar soap and body wash are sanitary, but loofahs, scrubbers, and washcloths, especially ones that are shared, are not . Be sure every member in your house only uses their own products and wash or replace these regularly! [9] X Research source

steps.title: Exfoliate your body once a week, focusing on acne-prone areas.
steps.content: Exfoliate your body once a week, focusing on acne-prone areas. [10] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Since the skin on your body produces more sweat and oil than the skin on your face, you may want to invest in a body scrub to use at least once a week. Using a clean washcloth or loofah, focus your gentle, circular motions on areas that are prone to breakouts, like the chest, neck, and back. Don't exfoliate too much because this can make body acne worse and irritate your skin. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Pat your body dry with a clean towel and apply lotion.
steps.content: Pat your body dry with a clean towel and apply lotion. The skin on your body is less delicate than your face, but it is still important to only use a clean towel to dry off. Stay in the humid, steamy bathroom and towel off until you are only a bit damp, and then apply moisturizer to your entire body before exiting. The steam helps with long-lasting hydration because the moisturizer sinks into your pores while they are still open.

steps.title: Wash your hands well and wash them often.
steps.content: Wash your hands well and wash them often. Cleaning the skin on your hands multiple times a day is extremely important for your health and for the health of others. Germs are everywhere, and some can make people very sick so it is important to wash your hands often, but especially: [12] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source After using the bathroom or changing a diaper After playing outside Before and after visiting anyone who is sick After blowing your nose or coughing, especially if you are sick Before eating, serving, or helping to make any food If your hands look dirty

steps.title: Use warm water and a mild soap.
steps.content: Use warm water and a mild soap. You can use an antibacterial soap if you prefer, but regular soap will work just as well. Just be sure to use soap every time you wash your hands! Rinsing with water might make your hands look clean, but they will still be covered in germs. This is important to do whether you are in a public restroom or at home, as germs and bacteria are everywhere. [13] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Clean all the surfaces of your hands.
steps.content: Clean all the surfaces of your hands. Don't just cup the soap in your hand and pass it back and forth between your palms. To really clean the skin on your hands, it is important to lather the soap onto both sides of the hands, in-between the fingers, under and around the nails, and up onto your wrists. You should do this for at least 20 seconds. [14] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Pat dry with a clean towel or fresh paper towel.
steps.content: Pat dry with a clean towel or fresh paper towel. If you are at home or a friend's house, be sure the hand towel is clean. If you are using a public restroom, use the paper towel to dry off your hands and then, still using the towel and not your bare hand, open the door and throw the towel away outside of the bathroom. A shocking number of people don't wash their hands after using the bathroom, and those handles collect a lot of germs. [15] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Moisturize your hands as needed.
steps.content: Moisturize your hands as needed. The skin on your hands might not need to be moisturized after every hand washing, but they can get chapped just like any other type of skin post-cleansing. Try carrying around a small tube of hand-specific moisturizer, which tend to be less greasy and sink in faster than other moisturizers, so you can keep your hands clean and soft.
